source.raw_text:
The Front-Rack Walking Lunge heavily targets your quads, glutes, and hamstrings, with significant engagement from your core (abs, lower back) for stability, plus activation in your calves and hip flexors, working through a fundamental bilateral unilateral pattern (one leg at a time) that improves balance, coordination, and functional strength. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked: 

• Primary Movers: 

    • Quadriceps: Extend the knee and control the descent. 
    • Glutes (Gluteus Maximus, Medius): Extend the hip and provide stability. 
    • Hamstrings: Work with glutes to extend the hip and flex the knee. 

• Stabilizers/Secondary Muscles: 

    • Core (Abs & Lower Back): Crucial for maintaining an upright torso and balance with the weight in front. 
    • Calves: Assist with ankle stability and propulsion. 
    • Hip Flexors: Help lift the leg forward. [1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7]  

Movement Pattern: 

• Bilateral/Unilateral: You perform the lunge on one leg (unilateral) before switching, but the weight is held with both hands (bilateral), challenging balance. 
• Sagittal Plane: The primary motion is forward and backward (stepping forward, returning), though you need lateral stability. 
• Eccentric & Concentric: Muscles lengthen (eccentric) controlling the lowering phase and shorten (concentric) pushing back up. 
• Functional Strength: It mimics natural walking, improving real-world movement and coordination. [3, 6, 8, 9, 10]  

How it Works: 
Holding the weight in the front rack position (across the shoulders) forces your core to work harder to keep your spine neutral, while the walking motion builds endurance and coordination in your legs. [1, 2, 5]
